awd_titl_txt: Osteoimmunology As A New Frontier in Treponemal Infection
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Fabian Crespo together with colleagues will undertake research to test the potential for integrating experimental osteoimmunology with bioarchaeology in reconstructing human host immune response and inflammatory phenotype (IP) focusing on immune responses against acquired syphilis's causal bacterium, Treponema pallidum; and ultimately explore how changes in inflammatory responses impact bone cell physiology. This project represents an experimental immunological complement to a more traditional bioarchaeological analysis (PI: Zuckerman), wherein host IP during the stages of infection will be reconstructed through biomarkers of other inflammatory conditions, specifically periodontal disease (PD). This project will establish the potential immunological interplay between systemic inflammatory responses against T. pallidum and other pathogens, such Porphyromonas gingivalis, which is causal to PD, and how this interplay may influence localized bone microenvironments, enabling skeletal biomarkers, such as PD, to be used to reconstruct IP with empirical certainty. Dr. Crespo and colleagues are committed to giving multiple public and K-12 lectures in collaboration with local and national educational organizations regarding health and social consequences of sexually transmitted infections (STIs), such as syphilis; and ultimately, emphasizing how the integration of skeletal analyses of disease in past populations, through bioarchaeology, with modern biomedical analysis, through osteoimmunology, can transform current understandings of human health. 

Dr. Crespo and colleagues will try to answer the following research questions: (1) Does exposing human immune cells to T. pallidum induce a systemic inflammatory shift that affects the host immune response to P. gingivalis; (2) Does exposing immune cells to P. gingivalis induce a shift that affects the host immune response to T. pallidum? (3) Does this potential shift have downstream effects on localized bone microenvironments, affecting bone cell differentiation and activity? (4) Lastly, can the potential inflammatory shift and physiological changes observed in vitro be associated with PD in skeletons with documented T. pallidum infection? These questions will be answered using peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) from healthy donors, splitting the cell population in two groups: a) whole PBMCs to explore evidence for an inflammatory shift when cells are alternatively exposed to antigens and lysates from T. pallidum and P. gingivalis; and b) isolated CD14+ monocytes, which differentiate into bone cells, from PBMCs (same donor), to assess how the potential shift might affect bone cell differentiation and activity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As proposed when submitting the original project, this is a high-risk and exploratory experimental study that planned to work with human cells from healthy donors, where the ultimate goal is to understand the interaction of activated or stressed immune cells by human pathogens (i.e. syphilis pathogen) and how these activated cells can “cross-talk” and affect human bone physiology. The study of the interplay between human immune and bone cells opens a new door of research that can deeply transform our understanding of human osteology and how can we explore and study the life and health of past populations.  The study of human remains, considering their archaeological contexts, allows emerging disciplines such as bioarchaeology to deeply explore how human bones can be studied as reservoirs of past human life histories and experiences. As expressed in the original proposal, if the bioarchaeological analysis is moving beyond simplistic interpretations of skeletal lesions as markers of ill health and it is searching for underlying physiological processes, experimental evidence is needed. The major outcome of this exploratory and high-risk project was to generate experimental evidence needed by osteological and paleopathological studies. When thinking about and developing this project, we proposed that a deep understanding of life histories, hidden in ancient human bones, needs to incorporate and employ information from modern experimental biomedical research. Consequently, our exploratory approach had the enormous challenge to be one of the first to start the “scientific dialogue” between modern experimental immunology and the study of human remains from archaeological contexts, especially considering how human chronic infections (such as syphilis) can affect human systemic health. One of the priorities of this novel experimental project was to include students (undergraduate and graduate) and to give them the opportunity to learn how we can conduct more comprehensive and interdisciplinary research. We are thrilled that despite the COVID-19 pandemic (that pushed us to close the laboratory for more than 1 year with a serious supply shortage) this project was able to help and produce 3 (three) theses: 2 undergraduate Honor Theses; and 1 Master Thesis in Anthropology. During the last 3 years, these students (Emily Rich, Michayla Gatsos, and Elijah Gardner) working at the University of Louisville had the great opportunity and experience to present our main results in more than 5 opportunities at meetings organized by the prestigious American Association of Biological Anthropologists (AABA) and the Paleopathological Association (PPA). The experimental data and evidence for the crosstalk between immune and skeletal systems are leading the way to continue working with prestigious colleagues. All three researchers in this project (Molly Zuckerman, Sharon DeWitte, and Fabian Crespo) received a second NSF in 2019 that will allow greater integration of experimental and osteological analysis. The PI of this NSF-EAGER (FC) recently obtained (2023) a collaborative institution NSF grant, with colleagues from George Mason University, to continue exploring the frontiers of osteoimmunology when reconstructing human health and disease in past populations. Also, PI (FC) started international collaborative projects with colleagues from the Universidad de Buenos Aires (Argentina) and Universidad Autonoma de Barcelona (Spain) with corresponding projects that are branching off the idea explored in this NSF-EAGER. All these collaborative projects are including students from the USA and local institutions. Finally, we are very proud to inform you that during the last AABA/PPA meetings (2023), we were invited to submit our work to be published in the prestigious journal Evolutionary Medicine and Public Health. This invitation clearly represents that our NSF-EAGER project was able to promote a new multidisciplinary dialogue when understanding how to integrate modern biomedical research to study health and disease in past populations.
